With Kubernetes, you get Cluster-level scheduling Horizontal Pod Autoscaling (HPA) Node health checks & self-healing Service discovery & load balancing ConfigMaps & Secrets Rollout's & rollbacks Enterprise-grade extensions (Istio, Prometheus, ArgoCD, etc.) And much more.. This is why nearly every enterprise company chooses Kubernetes. Did you know? Enterprise organization will typically run around thousands to millions of containers. And Kubernetes is designed to handle this scale efficiently. Google, Microsoft, Spotify & Open AI run thousands to millions of containers to serve their global user base.

You choose the tool based on your project‚Äôs needs.There is no wrong choice. If small project, one VM + few services, occasional downtime is fine ‚Üí Docker Compose If simple to medium project requiring multi-node ‚Üí Docker Swarm If large-scale, enterprise, microservices ‚Üí Kubernetes The important thing is to understand the trade-offs at each stage & make informed decisions. tip Docker swarm is still catching up with features compared to Kubernetes. At present, its a good middle ground for small to medium projects without Kubernetes complexity.

You learned the evolution of container orchestration from Docker to Docker Compose, Docker Swarm and finally Kubernetes. You understood the limitations at each stage and how the next tool addressed those limitations. You now know when to choose each tool based on project needs and scale.

Now that we have a basic understanding of k8's and have deployed our first pod, let's look into the high level architecture of k8's The main components of k8's architecture are Master Node (Control Plane) Can be multiple nodes for high availability Worker Node (Can be one or many nodes) Cluster is made up of multiple nodes (Master + Worker nodes) The Master Node takes care of administration task and consists of the following components API Server: The front-end for the Kubernetes control plane. It exposes the Kubernetes API & is the entry point for all the REST commands used to control the cluster. etcd: A consistent and highly-available key value store used as Kubernetes backlog store for all cluster data. Controller Manager: Runs controller processes. A controller is a small program that watches the cluster and makes sure things are in the desired state (E.g node controller, pod controller etc.,) Scheduler: Watches for newly created Pods with no assigned node, and selects a node for them to run on. Cloud Controller Manager: Lets you link your cluster into your cloud provider's API and separates out the components that interact with that cloud platform from components that just interact with your cluster. The Worker Node consists of the following components Kubelet: An agent that runs on each node in the cluster. It makes sure that containers are running in a Pod & kubelet communicates with the master node. Kube-Proxy: A network proxy that runs on each node in your cluster, it maintains network rules & handles routing of traffic to Pods from inside or outside the cluster. Container Runtime (CRI): The software that is responsible for running containers (E.g containerd, docker etc.,). K8's supports multiple container runtimes through the Container Runtime Interface (CRI). Pods: The smallest and simplest Kubernetes object. A pod represents a single instance of a running process/application in your cluster and can contain one or more containers.

In the previous section we saw that pods are the smallest deployable units in k8's. You created a pod using imperative command as well as declarative way using yaml. But what happens if the pod goes down due to some reason? Or what if you want to run multiple instances of the same pod for high availability? (For example, running 10 instances of nginx pod to handle more traffic) In such scenarios, managing pods directly becomes complex & cumbersome. To address these challenges, k8's provides higher level abstractions like Deployments on top of pods.

Let's see what Deployment is and how it helps to manage pods. A Deployment is a higher level abstraction over pods. It ensures that a specified number of pod replicas are running at any given time. If a pod goes down or crashed, the Deployment automatically creates a new pod to replace it, ensuring high availability. Deployments also split pods across multiple nodes for fault tolerance. You can also use Deployments to perform rolling updates to your application, allowing you to update your application without downtime.

First let' clean up all the previous pod or kubectl delete pod --all Let's create a deployment using imperative command kubectl create deployment nginx-deployment --image=nginx:1.28.0 --replicas=10 Now verify the deployment and pods are created and running using the below commands kubectl get pods -o wide Now lets delete one of the pods and see if deployment brings it back up to the desired state kubectl delete pod <your-pod-name> Now verify the pods again using the below command & this proves that deployment controller is bringing back the desired state kubectl get pods -o wide You can see the pods are spread across multiple nodes for fault tolerance. Note this depends on the number of nodes in your cluster. If you have only one node, all pods will be scheduled on the same node. Also if there are not enough resources (CPU or RAM) in the nodes, pods will be scheduled on the same node. In production, we don't deploy pods in control plane nodes for better performance and security. Let' rollout an update to the deployment to use a different nginx version kubectl set image deployment/nginx-deployment nginx=nginx:1.29.0 You can verify that it performs rolling update kubectl get pods -o wide Now let run this command & analyze the deployment details kubectl get deployments kubectl describe deployment nginx-deployment Lets delete the pods we need to delete the deployment using the below command kubectl delete deployment nginx-deployment

Let's create a deployment using declarative way using the below command apiVersion: apps/v1 kind: Deployment metadata: name: nginx-deployment labels: app: nginx-deployment spec: replicas: 3 selector: matchLabels: app: nginx-deployment template: metadata: labels: app: nginx-deployment spec: containers: - image: nginx name: nginx ports: - containerPort: 80 The selector field in Deployment helps to identify the pods that belong to the Deployment. So the matching happens based on labels. Save the above yaml file as deploy.yaml & run the below command to create the deployment kubectl apply -f deploy.yaml Observe the deployment created pods successfully kubectl get pods Now lets reduce the replicas to 2 in the deploy.yaml file, you can edit the deploy.yaml & save the file. Now let's apply the deployment using the below command kubectl apply -f deploy.yaml Now verify the deployment and pods are created and running using the below commands kubectl get pods -o wide tip A short command to check pods, deployments etc., is kubectl get all production tip In Production, we don't deploy using imperative commands. We use declarative way using yaml files or using tools like Helm Charts This helps to manage the infrastructure as code and version control. Also it helps to automate the deployment process using CI/CD pipelines. Also, we don't directly deploy pods in production, instead we use higher level abstractions like Deployments etc.,

A Deployment is a higher level abstraction that manages a set of identical pods. It ensures high availability by automatically replacing crashed pods and splitting pods across multiple nodes. Deployments also support rolling updates and rollback capabilities.

In the previous section we saw a high level overview of k8's architecture & also pods, Deployments & Namespaces concepts. By now you must be thinking, Hey! this is great, but are pods, deployments & namespaces are the only concepts in k8's ? Some of you might be wondering, how do we expose our applications running inside k8's to the outside world? To answer your questions, k8's has answers (K8's is really awesome!)

To give you a brief overview of different concepts in k8's Pods Deployments Namespaces Services ConfigMaps and Secrets Horizontal Pod Autoscalers Resource Requests and Limits Volumes and Persistent Volumes StatefulSets RBAC & Role Bindings Cron Jobs Daemon Sets Jobs Replication Controllers Storage Classes Network Policies Ingress Controllers And many more.. Each of these concepts solves a specific use case and rest assured, we will cover your common questions in the upcoming sections. Certification on K8's If you are interest in doing kubernetes certification, please refer to the official Kubernetes training website for more details.

Lets say now our organization has multiple teams working on different projects. All of them are using the same k8's cluster for their deployments. How do we manage the resources and deployments for different teams/projects? This is where Namespaces come into play.

A Namespace is a way to divide cluster resources between multiple users (teams/projects). Namespaces provide a isolated scope. You can use namespaces to separate environments between the different teams within the same cluster. You can see all the existing namespaces in the cluster using the below command: kubectl get namespaces As of now, we ave been using the default namespace for all our deployments. By default, if we don't specify any namespace, all the resources are created in the default namespace. You can create a namespace using the below command: kubectl create namespace project-stellar-dev Let's create a deployment in the newly created namespace using the below command: kubectl create deployment nginx-deployment --image=nginx --replicas=2 -n project-stellar-dev Now verify the deployment and pods are created and running in the project-stellar-dev namespace using the below commands: kubectl get pods -n project-stellar-dev -o wide For this workshop, we can use the default namespace. But in production, it's a good practice to create separate namespaces for different teams or projects. Production tip In production, we should not deploy directly to default namespace, instead we must create separate namespaces for different teams or projects.

Your pods are deployed & running, that's great (Pat yourself on the back!). But how do end users actually access your Pods or Deployments ? So far, we have learned We deployed Pods & we deployed multiple Pods using Deployments. A Deployment ensures we always run N replicas of the same Pod (identical instances). But when a user tries to access the application, they cannot directly talk to Pods. Pod IP's change frequently, Pods come and go & no guaranteed stability or discoverability. This is where Kubernetes Services come in.
A Service acts as a stable entry point to communicate with a set of Pods.
Pod IPs will change whenever a pod restarts & discoverability is difficult Clients need to know pod IPs ‚Üí bad practice (Don't do this in production!)

You get a stable, never-changing IP + DNS name Traffic is load-balanced across pods Only healthy pods receive traffic Kube-proxy handles routing & networking automatically Service sits in front of the Deployment, and all user requests pass through it.

When users hit the Service The Service selects pods based on selector labels kube-proxy forwards the request to one of the healthy pods The selection is usually in round-robin fashion (can be configured differently) If one pod is down, the Service automatically stops routing traffic to it This gives you built-in load balancing & self-healing routing.
Accessible only inside the cluster Good for microservices talking to each other Not accessible from outside world Example use cases: Backend ‚Üí Database API Server ‚Üí Redis Cache
Exposes a port on every node Node‚Äôs IP + NodePort ‚Üí reaches the Service Useful for learning/debugging, Not ideal for production Example: http://<node-ip>:30080/

Cloud provider creates an external load balancer (Azure LB, AWS ELB, GCP LB) Exposes a public endpoint User traffic ‚Üí Load balancer ‚Üí Service ‚Üí Pods Ideal for production-grade public access Recall the cloud controller manager from control plane architecture which is responsible for provisioning cloud resources like Load balancers etc., Example: http://52.10.25.13 (external Public IP)

First let's clean up the all the previous deployments kubectl delete deployment nginx-deployment or kubectl delete deployment --all Create a new deployment using the below yaml file nginx-deployment.yaml apiVersion: apps/v1 kind: Deployment metadata: name: nginx-deployment labels: app: nginx spec: replicas: 3 selector: matchLabels: app: nginx template: metadata: labels: app: nginx spec: containers: - image: nginx name: nginx ports: - containerPort: 80 Apply the deployment using the below command kubectl apply -f nginx-deployment.yaml Verify the deployment & pods are created and running using the below commands kubectl get deployments kubectl get pods -o wide Now create a ClusterIP service using the below imperative command kubectl expose deployment nginx-deployment --port=80 Verify the service is created using the below command kubectl get services Now lets understand a bit more using describe command kubectl describe service nginx-deployment You can see the service created endpoints for all the pods in the nodes To debug whether the service created & working we can use minikube service command minikube service list minikube service nginx-deployment Now lets create a clusterIp services using yaml file nginx-service.yaml apiVersion: v1 kind: Service metadata: name: nginx-cluster-ip labels: app: nginx spec: selector: app: nginx ports: - port: 80 protocol: TCP targetPort: 80 type: ClusterIP Quick question: How does above service know which pods to route the traffic to ? Answer: Using label selectors Lets delete the previous service kubectl delete service nginx-deployment Apply the service using the below command kubectl apply -f nginx-service.yaml Verify the service is created using the below command kubectl get services Now lets describe the service to see the details kubectl describe service nginx-cluster-ip You can see the service created endpoints for all the pods in the nodes To debug whether the service created & working we can use minikube service command minikube service list minikube service nginx-cluster-ip Lets create a NodePort service using the below yaml file nginx-node-port-service.yaml apiVersion: v1 kind: Service metadata: name: nginx-node-port labels: app: nginx spec: selector: app: nginx type: NodePort ports: - port: 80 protocol: TCP targetPort: 80 nodePort: 30080 Delete all the previous service kubectl delete service nginx-cluster-ip Apply the NodePort service using the below command kubectl apply -f nginx-node-port-service.yaml Now we use the minikube service command to verify the service is working minikube service nginx-node-port You should see the nginx welcome page in your browser Unfortunately, we cannot create LoadBalancer service in minikube as it requires cloud provider integration. Let's see that in action when we deploy in cloud provider like Azure. For completeness, here is the yaml for LoadBalancer service apiVersion: v1 kind: Service metadata: name: nginx-load-balancer labels: app: nginx spec: selector: app: nginx ports: - port: 80 protocol: TCP targetPort: 80 type: LoadBalancer Lets delete the previous service kubectl delete service nginx-node-port Apply the LoadBalancer service using the below command kubectl apply -f nginx-load-balancer-service.yaml Since we are using minikube, the external IP will be in pending state as minikube does not support LoadBalancer service. Recall the cloud controller manager from control plane architecture which is responsible for provisioning cloud resources like Load balancers etc., tip You can use kubectl get ep for getting the endpoints created for the services

Services connect to Pods using label selectors. Example: selector: app: myapp Any Pod with app: myapp will automatically be part of the Service‚Äôs backend. This allows Kubernetes to dynamically add/remove pods as Deployment scales up/down.

Let's say you have a python App app running in k8s cluster & it also needs to communicate to Node js backend service. important You can communicate with service name inside the cluster. For example, python app can reach the backend nodejs service using http://nodejs:4000 (assuming nodejs service is named nodejs and running on port 4000) This is because k8s has built-in DNS which resolves service names to their cluster IPs.

Pods run your app Deployments keep Pods running Services provide a stable access point to your Pods Services do load balancing + health-based routing Service types solve different access needs ClusterIP ‚Üí inside cluster NodePort ‚Üí node-level port LoadBalancer ‚Üí public access via cloud (k8s use cloud controller manager)
Now that we have understood the basic concepts of k8's, its time to practice what we have learned so far.

Make sure you have kubectl and minikube installed in your local machine. Make sure minikube cluster is up and running. Make sure you have the node app or python app setup from previous section 1 practice.

Go to the python or node js app folder from previous section 1 practice. Verify whether you logged in to the docker hub using the below command docker login Build the docker image using the below command docker build -t <your-dockerhub-username>/<image-name>:<tag> . Example: docker build -t sathish1996/node-app:1.0.0 . Push the docker image to docker hub using the below command docker push <your-dockerhub-username>/<image-name>:<tag> Example: docker push sathish1996/node-app:1.0.0 Now create a deployment yaml file deployment.yaml & service.yaml file & use the uploaded docker image in the deployment file. deployment.yaml apiVersion: apps/v1 kind: Deployment metadata: name: backend labels: app: backend spec: replicas: 3 selector: matchLabels: app: backend template: metadata: labels: app: backend spec: containers: - image: sathish1996/node-app:1.0.0 name: backend ports: - containerPort: 4000 service.yaml apiVersion: v1 kind: Service metadata: name: backend labels: app: backend spec: selector: app: backend type: NodePort ports: - port: 4000 protocol: TCP targetPort: 4000 nodePort: 30080 Apply the deployment using the below command kubectl apply -f deployment.yaml Apply the service using the below command kubectl apply -f service.yaml Verify the deployment & pods are created and running using the below commands kubectl get deployments kubectl get pods -o wide Expose the service using the below command minikube service backend If everything is done correctly you should be able to see the app running in the browser. Watchout for common issues like image pull issues, wrong image name/tag, container port is correctly mapped with the service target port. Now lets create a busybox pod to test the network connectivity to the backend service. Create a busybox pod using the below command kubectl run busybox --image=busybox --command -- sleep 3600 Exec into the busybox pod using the below command kubectl exec -it busybox -- sh Now inside the busybox pod use wget or curl to test the connectivity to the backend service using the service name and port. wget -qO- http://backend:4000 You should be able to see the response from the backend service & this shows that the service discovery is working fine. Congrats you have successfully deployed your first app in k8's cluster! tip kubernetes official documentation is great place to learn more kubernetes.io Quick Reference sheet for kubectl commands look here

Request We will cover the first 4 topics in this section. Before pausing for a QA break. Feel free to ask any blocking questions . The fourth topics will have a practice session, which involves some waiting time for the changes to reflect in minikube. So, it's better to pause there for questions for a while and continue after the break. In any application, we have certain configuration values that are required for the application to run. These configuration values are generally passed as environment variables. In K8's, we can pass environment variables to our pods using the env field in the pod specification. In the case of deployment we can pass environment variables in the same way as we do in pods. apiVersion: apps/v1 kind: Deployment metadata: name: backend labels: app: backend spec: replicas: 3 selector: matchLabels: app: backend template: metadata: labels: app: backend spec: containers: - image: sathish1996/node-app:1.0.0 imagePullPolicy: Always name: backend ports: - containerPort: 4000 env: - name: APP_NAME value: "I am awesome node app" - name: LOG_LEVEL value: "DEBUG"

You can edit the python app or node js app from previous practice to read the environment variable APP_NAME and return it in the response. app.get("/", (req, res) => { const env = { APP_NAME: process.env.APP_NAME, LOG_LEVEL: process.env.LOG_LEVEL, }; res.json({ message: "Environment Variables", env: env, }); }); Rebuild the docker image and push it to docker hub. Update the deployment yaml file to include the env variable as shown above. Cleanup the existing deployment using the below command kubectl delete deployment --all Apply the new deployment using the below command kubectl apply -f deployment.yaml Verify the pods are recreated using the below command kubectl get pods Access the application using the service & minikube service URL & verify the response contains the environment variable value. Tip: To debug the environment variables in the pod, you can exec into the pod and run the printenv command. kubectl exec -it <pod-name> -- sh printenv minikube kubectl -- exec -it <pod-name> -- sh printenv

In K8's, Secrets are used to store sensitive information such as passwords, OAuth tokens, and ssh keys. Secrets are similar to ConfigMaps but are specifically designed to hold confidential data. Secrets are stored in an encoded format (base64) to provide a basic level of security. We have multiple types of secrets like Opaque, Docker Registry, TLS, basic, ssh, k8's token etc. Important: While Secrets provide a basic level of security by encoding the data, they are not encrypted by default. important With native K8's secrets are not encrypted by default. For enhanced security, consider using additional encryption mechanisms or tools like K8's Encryption at Rest or external secret management solutions. Always follow best practices for managing sensitive data in your applications. In real projects, we store secrets in external secret management tools like HashiCorp Vault, AWS Secrets Manager, Azure Key Vault, Github Secrets, etc., and inject them into K8's at runtime. Managed K8's services like GKE, EKS, AKS provide integration with their respective secret management services for better security.

Opaque type Secrets can be created using yaml files. apiVersion: v1 kind: Secret metadata: name: app-secret type: Opaque data: # base64 encoded value of 'password123' injected from external secret # manager in production DB_PASSWORD: cGFzc3dvcmQxMjM= # base64 encoded value of 'apikey123456' # manager in production API_KEY: YXBpa2V5MTIzNDU2 Apply the secret using the below command kubectl apply -f secret.yaml Verify whether the secret is created using the below command kubectl get secrets Now update the deployment yaml to use the secret as shown below apiVersion: apps/v1 kind: Deployment metadata: name: backend labels: app: backend spec: replicas: 3 selector: matchLabels: app: backend template: metadata: labels: app: backend spec: containers: - image: sathish1996/node-app:1.0.0 imagePullPolicy: Always name: backend ports: - containerPort: 4000 envFrom: - configMapRef: name: app-config - secretRef: name: app-secret This will pass all the key value pairs from the secret as environment variables to the pod. Apply the deployment using the below command kubectl apply -f deployment.yaml Verify the pods are recreated using the below command kubectl get pods Use the below command to exec into the pod and verify the secret values are available as environment variables kubectl exec -it <pod-name> -- sh printenv minikube kubectl -- exec -it <pod-name> -- sh printenv

K8's Env are good but what if we have large number of configuration values or you need to share across multiple deployment.yaml files across services? In K8's, ConfigMaps are used to store non-confidential configuration data in key-value pairs. ConfigMaps allow you to decouple configuration artifacts from image content to keep containerized applications portable. ConfigMaps can be shared across multiple pods and can be updated independently of the pod lifecycle. ConfigMaps can be created using yaml files. apiVersion: v1 kind: ConfigMap metadata: name: app-config data: APP_NAME: "I am awesome node app" LOG_LEVEL: "DEBUG" ConfigMaps can be consumed in pods as environment variables or as configuration files in volumes. apiVersion: apps/v1 kind: Deployment metadata: name: backend labels: app: backend spec: replicas: 3 selector: matchLabels: app: backend template: metadata: labels: app: backend spec: containers: - image: sathish1996/node-app:1.1.1 imagePullPolicy: Always name: backend ports: - containerPort: 4000 env: - name: APP_NAME_CM valueFrom: configMapKeyRef: name: app-config key: APP_NAME - name: LOG_LEVEL_CM valueFrom: configMapKeyRef: name: app-config key: LOG_LEVEL Now deploy the configmap using the below command kubectl apply -f configmap.yaml Now update the deployment yaml to use configmap as shown above & apply the deployment using the below command kubectl apply -f deployment.yaml Verify the pods are recreated using the below command kubectl get pods Access the application using the service & minikube service URL & verify the response contains the configmap values. Tip: To debug the environment variables in the pod, you can exec into the pod and run the printenv command. kubectl exec -it <pod-name> -- sh printenv minikube kubectl -- exec -it <pod-name> -- sh printenv

Instead of passing each key value pair in the configmap.yaml, you can pass a whole key values using the below command apiVersion: apps/v1 kind: Deployment metadata: name: backend labels: app: backend spec: replicas: 3 selector: matchLabels: app: backend template: metadata: labels: app: backend spec: containers: - image: sathish1996/node-app:1.0.0 imagePullPolicy: Always name: backend ports: - containerPort: 4000 envFrom: - configMapRef: name: app-config This will pass all the key value pairs from the configmap as environment variables to the pod. Apply the deployment using the below command kubectl apply -f deployment.yaml Verify the pods are recreated using the below command kubectl get pods Access the application using the service & minikube service URL & verify the response contains the configmap values. Tip: To debug the environment variables in the pod, you can exec into the pod and run the printenv command. kubectl exec -it <pod-name> -- sh printenv minikube kubectl -- exec -it <pod-name> -- sh printenv Tip: Create a minikube service url by this command to access the application minikube service <service-name>

Let's imagine you have a pod running in a K8's Every pod will consume a certain amount of CPU and memory resources from the node it is scheduled on. Let's say your pod is consuming 1 CPU and 256MB memory.And there is a memory leak in your application which is causing the pod to consume more memory over time. What will happen when the pod exceeds the available memory on the node? The pod will be terminated by the K8's scheduler and will be restarted again & also node resources will be affected. To prevent this from happening, we can set resource requests and resource limits for the pod. Resource Requests specify the minimum amount of CPU and memory resources that a pod needs to run. Resource Limits specify the maximum amount of CPU and memory resources that a pod can use. By setting resource requests and limits, we can ensure that the pod has enough resources to run without being terminated due to resource exhaustion. tip When memory limit is reached, the pod will be terminated with an "Out of Memory" (OOM) error. When CPU limit is reached, the pod will be throttled, meaning it will be allowed to use only a certain percentage of CPU time. And you will see a drop in performance. Kubernetes does this to ensure that no single pod can monopolize the resources of a node, which could lead to resource starvation for other pods running on the same node.

Let's see in action about the OOM error when memory limit is reached. You can use the below yaml file to create a pod with resource requests and limits. apiVersion: v1 kind: Pod metadata: name: stress-test spec: containers: - name: stress-test image: polinux/stress command: ["stress"] args: ["--vm", "1", "--vm-bytes", "128M", "--timeout", "30s"] resources: requests: cpu: "1" memory: "50Mi" limits: cpu: "1" memory: "110Mi"
documents.s: Example of Pod with Resource Requests & Limits

documents.t: In a production environment, the load on an application can vary significantly over time. During peak hours, the application may experience a surge in traffic, leading to increased resource consumption. During off-peak hours, the load may decrease, resulting in underutilized resources. Scaling helps to adjust the resources allocated to an application based on the current load, ensuring optimal performance and cost-efficiency.

In general, there are two types of scaling - Horizontal Scaling and Vertical Scaling. Horizontal Scaling (Scaling Out/In) involves adding or removing instances, such as adding more servers to a cluster to handle increased load. Vertical Scaling (Scaling up/down) involves adding or removing resources to an existing instance, such as increasing the CPU or memory of a server to improve its performance. If this process is automated based on predefined conditions, it is referred to as Auto-scaling. if it is done manually, it is called Manual Scaling.

K8's has built-in support for horizontal scaling through the Horizontal Pod Autoscaler (HPA) resource. HPA automatically adjusts the number of pod replicas in a deployment based on observed CPU utilization or other select metrics. HPA continuously monitors the resource usage of pods and scales the number of replicas up or down to maintain the desired performance levels. Vertical Scaling in K8's is achieved through the Vertical Pod Autoscaler (VPA) resource. VPA automatically adjusts the resource requests and limits of pods based on observed resource usage. VPA continuously monitors the resource usage of pods and adjusts the resource requests and limits to optimize performance. Both HPA and VPA can be configured using yaml files or imperative commands.

K8's uses the Metrics Server to collect resource usage metrics from nodes and pods in the cluster. Kubelet on each node collects resource usage data and exposes it through the Kubelet API. The Metrics Server periodically scrapes the Kubelet API to gather resource usage metrics. The collected metrics are then made available to the HPA and VPA controllers in the control plane for scaling decisions. Metrics Server needs to be deployed in the cluster for HPA and VPA to function properly.
documents.s: How K8's collects metrics to start HPA & VPA?

documents.t: You can use the below yaml file to create a deployment with HPA enabled. apiVersion: apps/v1 kind: Deployment metadata: name: backend labels: app: backend spec: replicas: 2 selector: matchLabels: app: backend template: metadata: labels: app: backend spec: containers: - image: sathish1996/node-app:1.0.0 imagePullPolicy: Always name: backend ports: - containerPort: 4000 resources: requests: cpu: "100m" memory: "256Mi" limits: cpu: "200m" memory: "512Mi" Enable metrics server in te minikube cluster using below command: minikube addons enable metrics-server Wait for sometime for the metrics server to start, then verify the metrics server is running using below command: kubectl get deployment metrics-server -n kube-system We can also see the resource usage of nodes using below command: kubectl top nodes As we enabled the metrics server, we can now see the resource usage of pods using below command: kubectl top pods Let's port forward the deployment using below command & verify in browser kubectl port-forward deployment/backend 5001:4000 Now, we can create HPA for the deployment using below command: kubectl autoscale deployment backend --min=1 --max=5 --cpu-percent=3 You can notice the deployment replicas is set to 2 initially. But as we have set the HPA with min as 1 and max as 5, the hpa will be re-adjusted to 1 pod. This will take some time to reflect in minikube kubectl get hpa -w We can now generate some load on the deployment using curl tool in your powershell. while ($true) { curl http://localhost:5001 } As we generate load on the deployment, we can see the HPA is scaling the deployment replicas based on the CPU utilization. kubectl get hpa -w You can notice the replicas are increased to handle the load. kubectl get pods Stop the load, the HPA will scale down the replicas to the minimum value set. kubectl get hpa -w Congratulations! You have successfully implemented HPA in K8's.

By now you must have understood the importance of resource requests and limits in K8's. You have also learned about Horizontal and Vertical scaling in K8's. You have also seen HPA in action by creating a deployment with HPA enabled.

In K8's we have both ephemeral and persistent volumes. Ephemeral volumes are temporary and are deleted when the pod is deleted. Persistent volumes are long-lasting and can be reused by different pods & provide persistent storage. Volumes allow data to persist beyond the lifecycle of a pod, enabling data sharing between containers in a pod and across pod restarts. K8's supports various types of volumes like emptyDir, hostPath, StorageClass etc.

emptyDir is a type of ephemeral volume that is created when a pod is assigned to a node and exists as long as the pod is running on that node. Data in an emptyDir volume is stored on the node's filesystem and is deleted when the pod is removed from the node. emptyDir volumes are useful for temporary storage of data that does not need to persist beyond the lifecycle of the pod. Below is an example of how to use emptyDir volume in a pod specification. apiVersion: v1 kind: Pod metadata: name: emptydir-app labels: app: emptydir-app spec: volumes: - name: emptydir-volume emptyDir: {} containers: - name: busybox image: busybox command: ["sh", "-c", "sleep 3600"] volumeMounts: - name: emptydir-volume mountPath: /data In the above example, we have created a pod named emptydir-app with an emptyDir volume named emptydir-volume. The container writes a file hello.txt to the /data directory, which is mounted to the emptyDir Let's see how to create a pod with an emptyDir volume and verify its functionality. kubectl apply -f emptydir-pod.yaml Once the pod is running, we can exec into the container and create a file in the emptyDir volume. kubectl exec -it emptydir-app -- sh echo "Hello, World!" > /data/hello.txt exit Now, if we delete the pod and recreate it, we will see that the file hello.txt is no longer present, demonstrating the ephemeral nature of emptyDir volumes. kubectl delete pod emptydir-app kubectl apply -f emptydir-pod.yaml kubectl exec -it emptydir-app -- sh ls /data

Persistent Volumes (PVs) are a way to provide persistent storage in K8's. PVs are created by administrators. Persistent Volume Claims (PVCs) are requests for storage by users. PVCs can specify size, access modes, and storage class. It claims a piece of storage from a PV and binds to it. K8's Controller manages the binding between PVs and PVCs. Access modes define how the volume can be mounted (e.g., ReadWriteOnce, ReadOnlyMany, ReadWriteMany). Both the PV and PVC must have compatible access modes for successful binding. Example you cannot bind a PV with ReadWriteOnce access mode to a PVC requesting ReadOnlyMany access mode.

In static provisioning, an administrator creates a set of PVs that users can claim. In dynamic provisioning, K8's automatically provisions a PV when a PVC is created, based on the storage class specified in the PVC. Dynamic provisioning requires a storage class to be defined in the cluster. When a PVC is created with a specific storage class, K8's uses the provisioner defined in that storage class to create a new PV that meets the PVC's requirements. Storage classes contains the provisioner information and parameters needed for dynamic provisioning. Provisioners like kubernetes.io/aws-ebs, kubernetes.io/gce-pd, etc. are used to create PVs on different cloud providers. Storage classes has other parameters like reclaim policy, volume binding mode, etc. that define the behavior of the provisioned PVs. Storage classes also defines the type of storage (e.g., SSD, HDD)

Now let's say you don't need a PVC anymore, what happens to it? Reclaim policy defines what happens to a PV when its bound PVC is deleted. Common reclaim policies are Retain & Delete. Retain keeps the PV and its data intact for manual reclamation. Data is preserved. Delete removes the PV and its data from the cluster. Data is lost. Not recommended for production. The reclaim policy is set when the PV is created and can be modified later if needed.

As we are in local minikube, Let's try the to create a persistent volume in minikube nodes. First let ssh into minikube node to create a directory for volume. minikube ssh -n=minikube-m02 sudo mkdir -p /mnt/data sudo chmod 777 /mnt/data Let's go inside the mnt/data directory and create a file to verify persistence. cd /mnt/data echo "Persistent Data" > index.html exit Repeat the above step for minikube-m03 node as well. First let's create a persistent volume using hostPath volume type. apiVersion: v1 kind: PersistentVolume metadata: name: pv-volume spec: storageClassName: standard capacity: storage: 1Gi accessModes: - ReadWriteOnce hostPath: path: "/mnt/data" persistentVolumeReclaimPolicy: Retain Now apply the above PV configuration. kubectl apply -f pv.yaml Verify the PV status. kubectl get pv Now let's create a persistent volume claim to claim the above created PV. apiVersion: v1 kind: PersistentVolumeClaim metadata: name: pvc-volume-claim spec: storageClassName: standard accessModes: - ReadWriteOnce resources: requests: storage: 500Mi Now apply the above PVC configuration. kubectl apply -f pvc.yaml Verify the PV and PVC status. kubectl get pv kubectl get pvc You should see that the PVC is bound to the PV. Finally, let's create a pod that uses the above created PVC. apiVersion: v1 kind: Pod metadata: name: nginx-app labels: app: nginx-app spec: volumes: - name: nginx-storage persistentVolumeClaim: claimName: pvc-volume-claim containers: - name: nginx image: nginx volumeMounts: - name: nginx-storage mountPath: /usr/share/nginx/html ports: - containerPort: 80 Now apply the above pod configuration. kubectl apply -f pod.yaml Now let's verify if the data is persistent by accessing the nginx server. kubectl port-forward pod/nginx-app 8080:80 Open your browser and navigate to http://localhost:8080 to see the "Persistent Data" content. Now delete the pod and recreate it to verify data persistence. kubectl delete pod nginx-app kubectl apply -f nginx-pod.yaml kubectl port-forward pod/nginx-app 8080:80 Open your browser again and navigate to http://localhost:8080 to see that the "Persistent Data" content is still there, confirming that the data persisted across pod restarts or deletions. PRODUCTION TIP In production environments, it is recommended to use Persistent Volumes and Persistent Volume Claims for managing storage needs of applications. Use Dynamic Provisioning with appropriate Storage Classes to automate the creation of persistent volumes based on application requirements. Set the Reclaim Policy of persistent volumes based on data retention needs. Use Retain for critical data that needs to be preserved even after the PVC is deleted. Regularly monitor and manage the storage resources to ensure optimal performance and availability of applications.

We started with understanding the basic concepts of K8's like Pods, Deployments, Services, Namespaces etc. We understood the architecture of K8's and its components like Master Node, Worker Nodes, Kubelet, Kube-Proxy etc. We learned how to create and manage K8's resources using kubectl command & yaml files. We explored how to pass environment variables to pods using ConfigMaps and Secrets. We also saw how to manage application configuration using ConfigMaps and Secrets. we learned how to create and use Secrets for sensitive data like passwords, API keys, etc. We understood the importance of resource requests and limits in K8's. We explored Horizontal Pod Autoscaling (HPA) and how it helps in scaling applications based on resource utilization. We learned how K8's collects metrics using Metrics Server. Production tip In our production environments, we will use the combination of ConfigMaps and Secrets to manage application configuration and sensitive data. We will set appropriate resource requests and limits for our pods to ensure optimal resource utilization and prevent resource contention. We will implement Horizontal Pod Autoscaling (HPA) to automatically scale our applications based on resource utilization and traffic patterns. We will deploy using Deployments to ensure high availability and easy management of our applications. And expose only necessary services using Services to ensure security and accessibility of our applications. In Short, in production your application will be Secrets, ConfigMaps, Resource Management, HPA, Deployments and Services.

Imagine you have a web application running in a Kubernetes pod. Over time, the application might encounter issues like deadlocks or stuck in while loop (just for fun) causing it to become unresponsive. How does Kubernetes know when your application is healthy or ready to serve traffic? This is where Liveness Probes and Readiness Probes come into play. Liveness Probe checks if your application is alive. If it fails, Kubernetes will restart the pod. Readiness Probe checks if your application is ready to serve traffic. If it fails, Kubernetes will stop sending traffic to the pod until it passes again. You can configure these probes using HTTP requests, TCP sockets or command execution. Here's an example of how to define liveness and readiness probes in a Kubernetes deployment YAML: apiVersion: apps/v1 kind: Deployment metadata: name: nginx-deployment labels: app: nginx spec: replicas: 2 selector: matchLabels: app: nginx template: metadata: labels: app: nginx spec: containers: - name: nginx image: nginx:1.25 ports: - containerPort: 80 readinessProbe: httpGet: path: / port: 80 initialDelaySeconds: 5 # Wait 5s before starting checks periodSeconds: 5 # Check every 5s failureThreshold: 3 # After 3 failures ‚Üí pod marked Unready timeoutSeconds: 2 # Timeout for each check livenessProbe: httpGet: path: / port: 80 initialDelaySeconds: 10 # Wait 10s before checking liveness periodSeconds: 10 # Check every 10s failureThreshold: 3 # After 3 failed checks ‚Üí pod restarted timeoutSeconds: 2 # Timeout for each check You can deploy this YAML using kubectl apply -f deployment.yaml. Observe the log output to understand how probes checks periodically. kubectl logs -f <pod-name>

In Kubernetes, a Job is used to run a task to completion. It ensures that a specified number of pods successfully terminate. Once the task is completed, the pods are not restarted. A CronJob is used to run jobs on a scheduled basis, similar to cron jobs in Unix/Linux. You can define the schedule using standard cron syntax. Here's an example of a Job definition: apiVersion: batch/v1 kind: Job metadata: name: example-job spec: template: spec: containers: - name: example image: busybox command: ["echo", "Hello, World!"] restartPolicy: Never backoffLimit: 4 And here's an example of a CronJob definition: apiVersion: batch/v1 kind: CronJob metadata: name: example-cronjob spec: schedule: "*/5 * * * *" # Runs every 5 minutes jobTemplate: spec: template: spec: containers: - name: example image: busybox command: ["echo", "Hello from CronJob!"] restartPolicy: Never

A DaemonSet ensures that a copy of a pod runs on all (or some) nodes in a Kubernetes cluster. It is typically used for deploying system-level services like log collectors, monitoring agents, or network plugins. When new nodes are added to the cluster, the DaemonSet automatically schedules pods on those nodes. Here's an example of a DaemonSet definition: apiVersion: apps/v1 kind: DaemonSet metadata: name: example-daemonset spec: selector: matchLabels: app: example template: metadata: labels: app: example spec: containers: - name: example image: busybox command: ["sh", "-c", "while true; do echo Hello from DaemonSet; sleep 60; done"]

In Kubernetes, most workloads are stateless, meaning they don't retain any data between restarts. We use Deployments for such stateless applications. However, some applications require persistent storage and stable network identities. Examples include databases like MySQL, PostgreSQL, and distributed systems like Kafka. This is where StatefulSets come into play. A StatefulSet is a Kubernetes resource that manages the deployment and scaling of stateful applications. It provides guarantees about the ordering and uniqueness of pods. Key features of StatefulSets: Stable, unique network identifiers for each pod. Stable, persistent storage using PersistentVolumeClaims (PVCs). Ordered, graceful deployment and scaling of pods. Ordered, automated rolling updates. Here's an example of a StatefulSet definition for a simple MySQL database: apiVersion: apps/v1 kind: StatefulSet metadata: name: mysql spec: serviceName: "mysql" replicas: 3 selector: matchLabels: app: mysql template: metadata: labels: app: mysql spec: containers: - name: mysql image: mysql:5.7

Tolerations and Affinities are used to control pod scheduling in Kubernetes. Tolerations allow pods to be scheduled on nodes with specific taints. Affinities allow you to define rules for pod placement based on node labels and other criteria.

In Kubernetes, Roles and RoleBindings are used to manage access control within a namespace. A Role defines a set of permissions (like read, write, delete) for resources within a specific namespace. A RoleBinding associates a Role with a user or a group, granting them the permissions defined in the Role. Here's an example of a Role definition: apiVersion: rbac.authorization.k8s.io/v1 kind: Role metadata: namespace: default name: pod-reader rules: - apiGroups: [""] resources: ["pods"]

Till now we pulled the docker images from public docker hub repos. But in real time scenarios, we may have private docker repos to store our docker images. Lets first create a private repo in docker hub & push a sample private docker image. Go to docker hub & create a new private repo. You can push the backend service image from earlier section practice to the private repo.
documents.s: Using K8's Secrets to pull images from Private Docker Repositories

documents.t: Let's clean up all the existing deployments & services from previous practice. kubectl delete deployment --all kubectl delete service --all Now lets replace the deployment image with the private image from docker hub. apiVersion: apps/v1 kind: Deployment metadata: name: backend labels: app: backend spec: replicas: 3 selector: matchLabels: app: backend template: metadata: labels: app: backend spec: containers: - image: sathish1996/my-private-repo:1.0.0 imagePullPolicy: Always name: backend ports: - containerPort: 4000 envFrom: - configMapRef: name: app-config Apply the deployment using the below command kubectl apply -f deployment.yaml You will notice the pods will be in ErrorImagePull state because K8's is not able to pull the private image without authentication. kubectl get pods Analyse the error using the below command kubectl describe pod <pod-name> To fix this issue, we need to create a secret with docker registry credentials and link it to the deployment. Lets go to docker hub and create a PAT (Personal Access Token) for authentication. Create a docker secret using the below command kubectl create secret docker-registry my-private-secret --docker-email=your@gmail.com --docker-username=your-username --docker-password=your-docker-pat --docker-server=https://index.docker.io/v2/ Verify the secret is created using the below command kubectl get secrets Now update the deployment yaml to include the imagePullSecrets section as shown below Redeploy the deployment using the below command kubectl apply -f deployment.yaml Verify the pods are created and running using the below command kubectl get pods Access the application using the service & minikube service URL & verify the app is working fine in browser.

A big thank you for you all participating in the DevOps Part1 workshop! Hope you found it informative and helpful. You are now equipped with the knowledge to deploy and manage applications on local Kubernetes. Explore advanced topics to deepen your understanding. Kindly provide feedback on the workshop to help us improve future sessions. Lets plan end to end production grade k8's deployment workshop in future. Uninstall Rancher Desktop Uninstall Rancher Desktop from your system after the workshop or get explicit approval- IT team

You did it ! You have completed the K8's fundamentals. Now you have all the knowledge required to deploy a full stack application on Kubernetes. Your task is to deploy a simple web application that uses a frontend, backend and a database (Postgres, MySql or MongoDB). The frontend need to communicate with the backend, and the backend needs to communicate with the database. It can be a simple application like a TODO app or any other web application of your choice. The main goal of this exercise is to test your understanding of K8's concepts and your ability to deploy and manage applications on K8's. You need to create the necessary deployments, services, Secrets, ConfigMaps, HPA, resource limits, persistent volumes, liveness and readiness probes, StatefulSets etc.,. Good luck and happy k8's! Use ConfigMaps to pass configuration data to your application. Use Secrets to pass sensitive data like database passwords. Set appropriate resource requests and limits for your pods. Implement Horizontal Pod Autoscaling (HPA) to scale your application based on resource utilization. Use Persistent Volumes & Persistent Volume Claims (PVCs) to store data for your database. Expose your frontend using a Service of type NodePort for debugging. Use Liveness and Readiness probes to monitor the health of your pods. Use StatefulSets if your database requires stable network identities and persistent storage. You can use Deployments with pvc for databases as well. But its a production practice to use databases with StatefulSets. Refer to the previous sections for examples and guidance on how to create each component. Optional - You can use single yaml file with multiple documents separated by --- & have all your deployment, services etc., or multiple yaml files as per your preference. Optional - You can also try deploying using Helm Charts for better management. Read about Helm in the Helm Docs.
documents.s: K8's Zero to Hero - The Final Exercise

documents.t: Web application with frontend, backend & database

Use Branch Protection Rules: Enforce rules on branches to ensure code quality and prevent unauthorized changes. This includes requiring pull requests for changes, enforcing status checks, and restricting who can push to the branch. Code Owners & PR Templates: Use CODEOWNERS files to define who is responsible for code in specific directories. This helps in ensuring that the right people review changes. Also, use pull request templates to guide contributors on how to submit changes. Remove unused branches: Regularly clean up branches that are no longer needed. This helps in keeping the repository organized and reduces clutter. Use the git branch -d <branch-name> command to delete local branches, and git push origin --delete <branch-name> to delete remote branches.

Changing the remote Git repository URL in a local Git repository can be done using the git remote set-url command. This is useful when you want to switch from one remote repository to another, such as changing from a personal repository to an organizational one. git remote set-url origin https://sathish-thangavel@github.com/<org>/<repo>.git
If you want to set the local Git username and email for the repository, you can use the following commands: git config user.name "<Your Name>" git config user.email "<Your Email>"
documents.s: Set local git username and email

documents.t: If you want to set the global Git username and email, which will apply to all repositories on your machine, you can use the following commands: git config --global user.name "<Your Name>" git config --global user.email "<Your Email>"
documents.s: Set global git username and email

documents.t: To verify that the remote URL has been changed, you can use the following command git remote -v

You have just learned the basics of Docusaurus and made some changes to the initial template. Docusaurus has much more to offer! Have 5 more minutes? Take a look at versioning and i18n. Anything unclear or buggy in this tutorial? Please report it!

Read the official documentation Modify your site configuration with docusaurus.config.js Add navbar and footer items with themeConfig Add a custom Design and Layout Add a search bar Find inspirations in the Docusaurus showcase Get involved in the Docusaurus Community

Delete all GitHub Actions workflow runs from a repository using PowerShell and the GitHub CLI. While GitHub‚Äôs retention settings only clear the logs inside workflows, they don‚Äôt remove the workflow entries themselves. To solve this, we can write a PowerShell script as highlighted in the below blog Source Blog : Delete all github workflow runs using powershell Create a powershell script named run.ps1 param ( [string]$Owner, [string]$Repo ) if (-not (Get-Command gh -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue)) { Write-Host "GitHub CLI (gh) is not installed. Please install it from https://cli.github.com/" -ForegroundColor Red exit 1 } if (-not $Owner -or -not $Repo) { Write-Host "Usage: .\run.ps1 -Owner <GitHub-Owner> -Repo <GitHub-Repo>" -ForegroundColor Yellow exit 1 } $workflowRuns = gh api repos/$Owner/$Repo/actions/runs --paginate --jq '.workflow_runs[].id' foreach ($runId in $workflowRuns) { Write-Host "Deleting workflow run ID: $runId" gh api repos/$Owner/$Repo/actions/runs/$runId -X DELETE } Write-Host "All workflow runs have been deleted." This script does a few things: Accepts the owner and the repository as arguments. Run it as: .\run.ps1 -Owner <GitHub-Owner> -Repo <GitHub-Repo>. Avoids hard-coding values so it can run across different repositories easily. Checks if the GitHub CLI (gh) is installed by calling Get-Command on gh. Validates that both the owner and repository name are provided. Retrieves all workflow runs by calling the repos/$Owner/$Repo/actions/runs endpoint with --paginate to fetch all pages of results. For each workflow run ID, sends a DELETE request to repos/$Owner/$Repo/actions/runs/$runId to remove the run. Before running the script, make sure you‚Äôre authenticated with your GitHub account: gh auth login Once you logged in, call the script with a repo to which you have access and where you want to erase all workflow runs. Example command: .\run.ps1 -Owner glibnub -Repo waittimes-aggregator All the workflow runs will be deleted after this command

Transmission Control Protocol (TCP) is one of the core protocols of the Internet Protocol (IP) suite. It provides reliable, ordered, and error-checked delivery of data between applications running on hosts communicating over an IP network. TCP is widely used for applications that require guaranteed delivery, such as web browsing, email, and file transfers.
How to Increase Network TCP/IP Connections in Linux 1,000,000 Concurrent TCP Connections EC2 Tuning for +1M TCP Connections using Linux Redhat TCP Window Scaling
Docusaurus creates a page for each blog post, but also a blog index page, a tag system, an RSS feed...

Create a file at blog/2021-02-28-greetings.md: blog/2021-02-28-greetings.md --- slug: greetings title: Greetings! authors: - name: Joel Marcey title: Co-creator of Docusaurus 1 url: https://github.com/JoelMarcey image_url: https://github.com/JoelMarcey.png - name: S√©bastien Lorber title: Docusaurus maintainer url: https://sebastienlorber.com image_url: https://github.com/slorber.png tags: [greetings] --- Congratulations, you have made your first post! Feel free to play around and edit this post as much as you like. A new blog post is now available at http://localhost:3000/blog/greetings.
Documents are groups of pages connected through: a sidebar previous/next navigation versioning
Create a Markdown file at docs/hello.md: docs/hello.md # Hello This is my **first Docusaurus document**! A new document is now available at http://localhost:3000/docs/hello.

Docusaurus automatically creates a sidebar from the docs folder. Add metadata to customize the sidebar label and position: docs/hello.md --- sidebar_label: 'Hi!' sidebar_position: 3 --- # Hello This is my **first Docusaurus document**! It is also possible to create your sidebar explicitly in sidebars.js: sidebars.js export default { tutorialSidebar: [ 'intro', 'hello', { type: 'category', label: 'Tutorial', items: ['tutorial-basics/create-a-document'], }, ], };
Add Markdown or React files to src/pages to create a standalone page: src/pages/index.js ‚Üí localhost:3000/ src/pages/foo.md ‚Üí localhost:3000/foo src/pages/foo/bar.js ‚Üí localhost:3000/foo/bar

Create a file at src/pages/my-react-page.js: src/pages/my-react-page.js import React from 'react'; import Layout from '@theme/Layout'; export default function MyReactPage() { return (

My React page

This is a React page

 ); } A new page is now available at http://localhost:3000/my-react-page.
Create a file at src/pages/my-markdown-page.md: src/pages/my-markdown-page.md # My Markdown page This is a Markdown page A new page is now available at http://localhost:3000/my-markdown-page.
Docusaurus is a static-site-generator (also called Jamstack). It builds your site as simple static HTML, JavaScript and CSS files.
Build your site for production: npm run build The static files are generated in the build folder.

Test your production build locally: npm run serve The build folder is now served at http://localhost:3000/. You can now deploy the build folder almost anywhere easily, for free or very small cost (read the Deployment Guide).
Docusaurus supports Markdown and a few additional features.

Markdown documents have metadata at the top called Front Matter: my-doc.md --- id: my-doc-id title: My document title description: My document description slug: /my-custom-url --- ## Markdown heading Markdown text with [links](./hello.md)

Regular Markdown links are supported, using url paths or relative file paths. Let's see how to [Create a page](/create-a-page). Let's see how to [Create a page](./create-a-page.md). Result: Let's see how to Create a page.

Regular Markdown images are supported. You can use absolute paths to reference images in the static directory (static/img/docusaurus.png): ![Docusaurus logo](/img/docusaurus.png) You can reference images relative to the current file as well. This is particularly useful to colocate images close to the Markdown files using them: ![Docusaurus logo](./img/docusaurus.png)

Markdown code blocks are supported with Syntax highlighting. ```jsx title="src/components/HelloDocusaurus.js" function HelloDocusaurus() { return

Hello, Docusaurus!

; } ``` src/components/HelloDocusaurus.js function HelloDocusaurus() { return

Hello, Docusaurus!

; }

Docusaurus has a special syntax to create admonitions and callouts: :::tip[My tip] Use this awesome feature option ::: :::danger[Take care] This action is dangerous ::: My tip Use this awesome feature option Take care This action is dangerous

MDX can make your documentation more interactive and allows using any React components inside Markdown: export const Highlight = ({children, color}) => ( { alert(`You clicked the color ${color} with label ${children}`) }}> {children} ); This is Docusaurus green ! This is Facebook blue ! This is Docusaurus green ! This is Facebook blue !
Let's translate docs/intro.md to French.
Modify docusaurus.config.js to add support for the fr locale: docusaurus.config.js export default { i18n: { defaultLocale: 'en', locales: ['en', 'fr'], }, };

Copy the docs/intro.md file to the i18n/fr folder: mkdir -p i18n/fr/docusaurus-plugin-content-docs/current/ cp docs/intro.md i18n/fr/docusaurus-plugin-content-docs/current/intro.md Translate i18n/fr/docusaurus-plugin-content-docs/current/intro.md in French.

Start your site on the French locale: npm run start -- --locale fr Your localized site is accessible at http://localhost:3000/fr/ and the Getting Started page is translated. caution In development, you can only use one locale at a time.

To navigate seamlessly across languages, add a locale dropdown. Modify the docusaurus.config.js file: docusaurus.config.js export default { themeConfig: { navbar: { items: [ { type: 'localeDropdown', }, ], }, }, }; The locale dropdown now appears in your navbar:
Build your site for a specific locale: npm run build -- --locale fr Or build your site to include all the locales at once: npm run build
Docusaurus can manage multiple versions of your docs.

Release a version 1.0 of your project: npm run docusaurus docs:version 1.0 The docs folder is copied into versioned_docs/version-1.0 and versions.json is created. Your docs now have 2 versions: 1.0 at http://localhost:3000/docs/ for the version 1.0 docs current at http://localhost:3000/docs/next/ for the upcoming, unreleased docs

To navigate seamlessly across versions, add a version dropdown. Modify the docusaurus.config.js file: docusaurus.config.js export default { themeConfig: { navbar: { items: [ { type: 'docsVersionDropdown', }, ], }, }, }; The docs version dropdown appears in your navbar:

It is possible to edit versioned docs in their respective folder: versioned_docs/version-1.0/hello.md updates http://localhost:3000/docs/hello docs/hello.md updates http://localhost:3000/docs/next/hello
